awd_titl_txt: Exploration-exploitation tradeoff and opinion diversity in real-world groups
awd_abstract_narration:
Communities oscillate between exploring new solutions to problems and exploiting existing ones, depending on the task at hand. As a consequence, the diversity of opinions about possible solutions waxes and wanes over time. How these changes in diversity of opinion affect group performance is an open question, with extant studies finding both positive and negative effects. This project will investigate whether these inconsistent findings can be explained by how diversity interacts with task complexity and group threat. Higher diversity of opinions about possible solutions can be adaptive when groups face complex tasks, while lower diversity can help in collective solving of simple tasks. In addition, groups that have more homogeneous views, and are therefore better coordinated, often have an advantage in intergroup conflict. As a consequence, when group threat leads to decreased diversity of opinions, it might have negative effects on performance in complex tasks, but neutral or even positive effects for simple tasks. Furthermore, groups can be expected to use strategies to adaptively manipulate their level of diversity according to task complexity and experienced threat. This project will therefore also investigate the adaptive value of such strategies, including policing, ostracism, and denigrating outgroups. Overall, understanding factors that promote or suppress the diversity of opinions is immensely important today for national security issues. Current communication technologies offer unprecedented opportunities for interactions with many different people, and yet they also seem to facilitate formation of relatively isolated communities of people with similar opinions. Better theoretical and empirical understanding of factors that influence the diversity of opinions in real-world communities, and that moderate the value of diversity for finding good societal solutions, is necessary for maintaining and promoting a healthy democratic dialogue. To promote further research in this area, the project will also provide unique training opportunities for students at the intersection of cognitive and social sciences, computational linguistics, and network science, and include two interdisciplinary working groups discussing promising directions for theoretical and methodological progress in understanding diversity in modern societies.

To study how task complexity and group threat influence opinion diversity and the resulting group performance, and to investigate mechanisms that real-world communities use to manage their diversity in response to these factors, the project will first integrate several previously disconnected literatures on exploration-exploitation trade-offs, group behavior and decision making under threat, social learning, altruistic punishment, ostracism, and stereotyping. The resulting hypotheses will be tested using three different methodologies: computational modeling, group experiments, and computational linguistics analyses of discussions on online news sites involving thousands of users over prolonged time periods. This will allow for robustness checks and mitigation of risks of relying on only one method. These theoretical and methodological developments will foster further scientific research of modern human sociality.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we investigate how the diversity of opinions in groups changes in response to threat from other groups and to problems of different complexity. Groups that are more cohesive and coordinated can have an advantage in conflicts over groups that are more diverse. An outside threat to group integrity, whether imaginary or real, could affect the group's opinion diversity. In turn, the diversity of opinions can influence group performance, but the direction of influence depends on problem complexity. For simple problems, diversity can slow down convergence on the correct answer, while for complex problems, maintaining diversity can aid the discovery of good solutions that are not immediately obvious.

The relationship between perceived group threat and opinion diversity is becoming more and more important in the modern information environment where information about real and imagined threat of 'others' spreads rapidly and where, at the same time, collective solving of complex problems such as climate change or pandemics is more important than ever. However, previous findings on this issue have been mixed, and there was a lack of theoretical integration as well as of empirical data from large-scale real-world settings. To make progress, we integrate the literature on exploration-exploitation benefits for tasks of different complexity with the literature on group threat from social psychology, and develop a new framework where decrease in diversity because of threat can have positive effect for simple but negative for complex tasks. We use diverse methodologies to empirically test our hypotheses, from simulations and group experiments to analyses of millions of comments posted in discussions on news sites over nine years and five different news sites spanning the extremes of the U.S. political spectrum.

Our results suggest that collective dynamics changes when groups perceive threat from an outside group. The changes occur on the level of social networks, expressed opinions, and collective performance. Specifically, some members become more influential, expressed opinions become more similar, and collective performance changes depending on task complexity. We use these and related findings from our studies to develop further novel theoretical frameworks for studying belief dynamics and collective adaptation. We contribute to an open-source platform for conducting group experiments, and provide unique training opportunities for researchers at the intersection of cognitive and social sciences, computational linguistics, and network science. Our results also have broad implications for collective coping with our increasingly complex information systems environment. While it is not always realistic or advisable to intentionally disregard potential outgroup threat, awareness of its possible consequences for collective dynamics might help societies to choose their priorities and find ways to preserve diversity of opinions even in times of threat.
